text: <@U02CVNB3X1T> — I run an agency too. This was a long and painful thing for us to understand. First you need to track time for everything. Without that data, this is impossible to figure out—and you need the data over several months of time so you can get averages. I have never ever seen our team members complete a blog in 2 hours. I made the mistake of basing pricing on my freelancing when I started too—I had to about 10x the pricing if not more now that I have a team. But basically you can't assume this or guess, you need the data over several months of time and then you'll have to have difficult conversations with your clients

elements.text: — I run an agency too. This was a long and painful thing for us to understand. First you need to track time for everything. Without that data, this is impossible to figure out—and you need the data over several months of time so you can get averages. I have never ever seen our team members complete a blog in 2 hours. I made the mistake of basing pricing on my freelancing when I started too—I had to about 10x the pricing if not more now that I have a team. But basically you can't assume this or guess, you need the data over several months of time and then you'll have to have difficult conversations with your clients

text:
we're also working on this at the consulting firm I work for — as Maeva said, we're currently working on tracking exactly how much time tasks really do take so that we're able to build in a little buffer as well as account for all the ad-hoc items that come up. it's been helpful to do that as well! I'd start by asking each person how long they THINK it takes them for each task, then asking them to actually time themselves so they can get a better idea.

I think it's also hard to come up with a true average for every person, since I'm assuming that each person has a slightly different process, so it might be better to assume that it'll fall somewhere within a range... but hopefully getting started with this process will help!

elements.text:
we're also working on this at the consulting firm I work for — as Maeva said, we're currently working on tracking exactly how much time tasks really do take so that we're able to build in a little buffer as well as account for all the ad-hoc items that come up. it's been helpful to do that as well! I'd start by asking each person how long they THINK it takes them for each task, then asking them to actually time themselves so they can get a better idea.

I think it's also hard to come up with a true average for every person, since I'm assuming that each person has a slightly different process, so it might be better to assume that it'll fall somewhere within a range... but hopefully getting started with this process will help!

text: one other thing you mention is the concept of scope creep — something else to consider is whether or not you have clear guidelines for your team on what is or is not included in a particular task, and a process they can use if the client pushes for more than is technically included.

elements.text: one other thing you mention is the concept of scope creep — something else to consider is whether or not you have clear guidelines for your team on what is or is not included in a particular task, and a process they can use if the client pushes for more than is technically included.

text: Yes! This is huge. I defined scope creep for myself and our small core team, and as the team grew it took a few months of wondering "why are they spending so much time on this client??" to realize they were doing things I had already set boundaries for a while back

elements.text: Yes! This is huge. I defined scope creep for myself and our small core team, and as the team grew it took a few months of wondering "why are they spending so much time on this client??" to realize they were doing things I had already set boundaries for a while back

text: These are all great comments! I think for us too, our main problem is that we offer clients a “package for 50 hours” and they package is full of estimated deliverables that don't have times associated to it. So yeah, let's sell 50 hours…but the reality is…that 50 is more like 100.

elements.text: These are all great comments! I think for us too, our main problem is that we offer clients a “package for 50 hours” and they package is full of estimated deliverables that don't have times associated to it. So yeah, let's sell 50 hours…but the reality is…that 50 is more like 100.

text: Heya <@U014ZK7Q1TP>, I’ve actually done a few of these reports in the past all in-house. Our focus was always pulling, analyzing, and sharing our own data (for SaaS companies). There’s definitely a learning curve and a lot of testing/iterating, but it’s definitely do-able, depending on your in-house resources. I had help pulling/analyzing the data (but still did a lot of the leg work and coordinating) and had help on the design side for the report/assets. Obviously different than surveying an industry/external audience, but wayyy cheaper and still a great way to share some meaningful data. And these assets always performed well, people love data!

elements.text: Heya

I had help pulling/analyzing the data (but still did a lot of the leg work and coordinating) and had help on the design side for the report/assets. Obviously different than surveying an industry/external audience, but wayyy cheaper and still a great way to share some meaningful data. And these assets always performed well, people love data!

text: Hey <@U014ZK7Q1TP>, late to the party but a 'backdoor' way into this would be to look at working with trade publications / media companies. I've found, depending on niche, they under price this offering massively vs typical market research firms. Odd given they typically have large trusted networks, skilled writers and a ready made audience for deployment. Not always but might be worth a thought.

text: They can be tricky to find for obvious reasons but here's an example of one's the company I work with have done. Please excuse the design of these :slightly_smiling_face: - on my list to change these - <https://www.fasken.com/en/knowledge/2020/12/energy-in-africa-report> & <https://www.energyvoice.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/4/2021/01/Energy-Voice-Guyana-Playbook-December-2020.pdf>   the cost to produce these via a publisher vs research company surprised me. Therefore be plenty of publisher who won't have this down commercially and I am sure would welcome that conversation.

text: Hey All! What companies do you think have done the best repurposing event content post event? I.e. -- repackaging their session into blogs, emails, social posts, videos, etc. I'm working on a project to help a client do just that and would love some inspiration!

elements.text: Hey All! What companies do you think have done the best repurposing event content post event? I.e. -- repackaging their session into blogs, emails, social posts, videos, etc. I'm working on a project to help a client do just that and would love some inspiration!

text: <@UV773Q98Q> Would you be willing to share what the cost was on these? Or even a ballpark figure?

elements.text: Would you be willing to share what the cost was on these? Or even a ballpark figure?

text:
Wouldn’t say we’re the *best* at it (yet!), but here’s an example of how we repurpose a webinar into a blog at Butter: <https://www.butter.us/blog/designing-engaging-workshops>

We also repurposed most of the tips into individual social posts.

*Edit:* For <https://www.butter.us/blog/remote-connections|this blog> I also pulled out a few highlight clips from the workshop and plunked them into the blog. We also used the standalone clips on social, which did well.

text: I’ve worked on a few of these kinds of projects for Webflow (repurposing conference talks as blog posts <https://webflow.com/blog/ncc-india-no-code-covid|here> and <https://webflow.com/blog/ncc-2021-uncommon-microsites|here>) and for Monte Carlo (a conference panel with an industry leader as a <https://www.montecarlodata.com/blog-the-future-of-the-modern-data-stack/|blog post>). Pretty straightforward, but one of my favorite content tactics to get some good longform articles out of existing videos!

attachments.fallback: Webflow: How no-code tools helped during India’s COVID surge | Webflow Blog
attachments.text: Learn how no-code builder Vensy Krishna’s app helped thousands of people access lifesaving resources during India’s national COVID-19 crisis.
attachments.title: How no-code tools helped during India’s COVID surge | Webflow Blog

attachments.fallback: Webflow: Creating uncommon microsites with Webflow | Webflow Blog
attachments.text: Learn how Webflow wizard Timothy Ricks creates uncommon microsites with Webflow by focusing on value over conversions and crafting moments of delight.
attachments.title: Creating uncommon microsites with Webflow | Webflow Blog

attachments.fallback: Monte Carlo Data: What's In Store For The Future Of The Modern Data Stack?
attachments.text: Bob Muglia, the former CEO of Snowflake, discusses what’s next for the tooling and technologies powering data analytics and engineering.
attachments.title: What's In Store For The Future Of The Modern Data Stack?

text: We’re also doing our best over here at Knotch! Our podcasts also get audiograms and <https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6907716773899345921|pull-quote images>. I’ve done <https://knotch.com/blog/is-your-content-thumb-stopping/|blog posts w/ embedded videos> for events in the past, too.

text: Why not move to a project-based fee model for clients and writers? This would help you on both the client side (they know exactly what deliverables they're getting) and if you're outsourcing to a team it would definitely simplify things there. You know what the market rate is for a blog -- how long it takes your team to do it becomes a moot point. I guess if it's an in-house team it could be more challenging as you need to manage capacity.

elements.text: Why not move to a project-based fee model for clients and writers? This would help you on both the client side (they know exactly what deliverables they're getting) and if you're outsourcing to a team it would definitely simplify things there. I guess if it's an in-house team it could be more challenging as you need to manage capacity.
